facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 373 of 1956 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 17, 1952 of the Madras High Court in A.S. No. 270 of 1948

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 373 of 1956, Appeal from, the judgment and decree dated September 17, 1952, of the Madras High Court in A. S. No. 270 of 1948. V. Viswanatha Sastri, A. V. Narayanaswami and S. Narasimhan for T. K. Sundara Raman, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 23, 1961 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. February 23. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This appeal raises a short question about the construction of a will executed by the testator, Diraviyam Pillai, on April 28, 1937,

facts.text: Testator Diraviyam Pillai executed will on April 28, 1937

anchor.surface_text: construction of a will executed by the testator, Diraviyam Pillai, on April 28, 1937, and it arises from a suit instituted by the appellant N. Kasturi in the Court of the Subordinate Judge at Madura.

facts.text: Testator Diraviyam Pillai died on March 10, 1939

anchor.surface_text: As we have already seen the testator executed the will on April 28, 1937, and he died on March 10, 1939. During his lifetime the testator was a member of a joint and undivided Hindu family consisting of himself and his son,

facts.text: Thayumanaswami Pillai died on May 9, 1935 leaving two widows respondent 2 Mangayarkarasi Ammal and respondent 3 Kanniammal and widowed daughter respondent 4 Pichai Ammal

anchor.surface_text: During his lifetime the testator was a member of a joint and undivided Hindu family consisting of himself and his son, Thayumanaswami Pillai. Neither of them had any son. At his death which took place on May 9,1935, Thayumanaswami Pillai left behind him two widows, respondent 2, Mangayarkarasi Ammal and respondent 3, Kanniammal, and a widowed daughter by the former, respondent 4, Pichai Ammal.

facts.text: Testator became entitled to whole family property by survivorship after son's death

anchor.surface_text: The testator who survived his son became entitled to the whole of the family property by survivorship, and it is as such that he made, and was competent to make, the will in question.

facts.text: Appellant N. Kasturi is the testator's sister's daughter's grandson

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the sisters daughters grandson of the testator, whereas Kalyanasundaram, respondent 5, was treated as a foster-son by the testators son, Thayumanaswami Pillai.

facts.text: Kalyanasundaram respondent 5 treated as foster-son by testator's son Thayumanaswami Pillai

anchor.surface_text: whereas Kalyanasundaram, respondent 5, was treated as a foster-son by the testators son, Thayumanaswami Pillai. Respondent 5 died pending the appeal before this Court leaving behind him two widows, two minor sons and two minor daughters who have been brought on the record as his heirs and legal representatives.

facts.text: Respondent 5 died pending the appeal before this Court leaving two widows two minor sons and two minor daughters brought on record as heirs

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 5 died pending the appeal before this Court leaving behind him two widows, two minor sons and two minor daughters who have been brought on the record as his heirs and legal representatives. These are the persons who have been mentioned in the will and who appear to be the objects of the testators bounty in one way or another.

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit in Court of Subordinate Judge at Madura claiming rights under clause 12 of the will

anchor.surface_text: and it arises from a suit instituted by the appellant N. Kasturi in the Court of the Subordinate Judge at Madura. In his suit the appellant alleged that under cl. 12 of the will certain rights either vested or contingent had been conferred on him in regard to the property as therein described,

facts.text: Trial court construed will against appellant holding no right conferred on him

anchor.surface_text: The trial court construed the will against the appellant and held that it conferred no right on him and so he could no claim any of the reliefs set out in his plaint. Incidentally, on the merits the trial court was satisfied that a case had been made out by the appellant

facts.text: Trial court found estate was being wasted by respondent 1 Ponnammal

anchor.surface_text: that a case had been made out by the appellant and that it did appear that the estate was being wasted by its present holder, respondent 1. The appellant then took the matter before the Madras High Court by his appeal.

facts.text: Madras High Court agreed with trial court that appellant had no right under the will

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has agreed with the trial court in the construction of the will. It has held that the appellant had no right under the will which would justify his claim for any of the reliefs set out in his plaint. On that finding the High Court thought it unnecessary to consider the merits of the case

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate from High Court and appealed to Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: On that finding the High Court thought it unnecessary to consider the merits of the case set out by the appellant and denied by respondent 1. The appellant then applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court, and it is with the said certificate that he has come to this Court by his present appeal

facts.text: Testator executed earlier will on June 12, 1935 which was registered

anchor.surface_text: Clause 1 of the will refers to the fact that the testator had already executed a will on June 12, 1935, and had registered it. The present will was executed by him with a view to cancel his earlier will

facts.text: Testator and his son were members of undivided Hindu family and acquired property

anchor.surface_text: Clause 2 of the will states that the testator and his senior son, the deceased Thayumanaswami Pillai, were members of an undivided Hindu family and as such had acquired property and carried on money-lending business in the names of both of them.

facts.text: Testator was 64 years old and had no issue with wife respondent 1 Ponnammal

anchor.surface_text: Clause 3 recites that the testator was then 64 years of age and that he and his wife, respondent 1, had no issue. Then he refers to his other relations in whom he was interested.

facts.text: Ponnammal respondent 1 is testator's widow in charge of the estate

anchor.surface_text: with a view to protect his interest and safeguard the estate from being wasted by, and lost in the hands of, the testators widow, respondent 1, Ponnammal, who was in charge of the said estate.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds clause 12 of will operates only at time of testator's death and appellant gets no right under it since widow survived testator

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that reading cls. 11 and 12 together the High Court was right in holding that cl. 12 was intended to operate at the time of the death of the testator and not later and that the appellant would get an interest under cl. 12 only if the widow of the testator predeceased the testator

facts.text: No adoption made by testator during lifetime

anchor.surface_text: Clauses 6 to 11 deal primarily with the adoption which the testator contemplated would be made by his widow in case he did not make an adoption in his lifetime.

facts.text: Appellant not adopted by respondent 1

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the appellants rights are provided for by cl. 11 alone, and those rights cannot come into existence unless and until he is adopted by respondent 1.

facts.text: Testator's wife Ponnammal survived testator

anchor.surface_text: that the appellant would get an interest under cl. 12 only if the widow of the testator predeceased the testator and there is no adoption by the testator before his death.

facts.text: High Court did not consider merits of wastage claim

anchor.surface_text: On that finding the High Court thought it unnecessary to consider the merits of the case set out by the appellant and denied by respondent 1.
The testator who survived his son became entitled to the whole of the family property by survivorship, and it is as such that he made, and was competent to make, the will in question.

issues.text: Have the courts below put an unreasonable construction on the will as Mr. Viswanatha Sastri for the appellant contends?

anchor.surface_text: and so, the only question which falls for our decision is Have the courts below put an unreasonable construction on the will as Mr. Viswanatha Sastri for the appellant contends? As we have already seen the testator executed the will on April 28, 1937, and he died on March 10, 1939.

issues.text: Does the appellant get any right under cl. 12 of the will which would justify his claim for a declaration and other appropriate reliefs made by him in the present suit?

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for our decision is Does the appellant get any right under cl. 12 of the will which would justify his claim for a declaration and other appropriate reliefs made by him in the present suit ? As we have already indicated, both the courts below have answered this question against the appellant.

issues.text: Should cl. 12 be construed as operating at the time of the death of the testator and not later?

anchor.surface_text: the respondents case, however, is, and that is the case which has been accepted by the courts below, that cl. 12 should be construed as operating at the time of the death of the testator and not later, and according to this argument, as soon as the testator died the said clause ceased to be applicable and the rights of the appellant fall to be considered only under cl. 11.

issues.text: Does cl. 12 confer a vested right in respect of half the properties in the appellant subject to defeasance by subsequent adoption?

anchor.surface_text: His argument is that when no adoption is made and until it is so made there is a vested right in respect of half the properties in the appellant which right no doubt may be defeated if an adoption is subsequently made. He contends that this is a vested right subject to defeasance by subsequent adoption, and this right has nothing to do with the right which would be conferred on the appellant if he is adopted as contemplated by cl. 11.

issues.text: Should 'myself and my wife' in cl. 12 be read as 'myself or my wife' to avoid joint adoption interpretation?

anchor.surface_text: If the appellants argument was accepted the first part of the clause would have to be split up into two and would have to be read as conferring the failure of the testator or that of his wife to make an adoption. In other words, the expression myself and my wife has to be read as myself or my wife , and in the context that seems inappropriate.

precedents.citation: Sarojini Dassi V.Gnanendranath Das Others etc.  1

anchor.surface_text: Sarojini Dassi V.Gnanendranath Das Others etc.  1 . On a companystruction of the several dispositions companytained in the will with which the learned judge was dealing he came to the companyclusion that taken together the said dispositions show that the testator intended to dispose of all his properties, and then he added if there is any doubt, we ought if possible to read the will so as to lead to a testacy, number to an intestacy.

precedents.cited_proposition: if there is any doubt, we ought if possible to read the will so as to lead to a testacy, not to an intestacy

anchor.surface_text: In re Redfern 2 , In re Harrison  3 , Kirby Smith v. Parnell  4  and In re Edwards  5 . In support of the second principle enunciated by Mr. Sastri he has relied on the decision of the Privy Council in Bickersteth Another v. Shanu 6 .

In re Harrison  3 , Kirby Smith v. Parnell  4  and In re Edwards  5 . In support of the second principle enunciated by Mr. Sastri he has relied on the decision of the Privy Council in Bickersteth Another v. Shanu 6 . In that case the Privy Council held that the established rule for construing devises of real estate is that they are held to be vested unless a condition precedent to the vesting is expressed with reasonable clearness.

Kirby Smith v. Parnell  4  and In re Edwards  5 . In support of the second principle enunciated by Mr. Sastri he has relied on the decision of the Privy Council in Bickersteth Another v. Shanu 6 . In that case the Privy Council held that the established rule for construing devises of real estate is that they are held to be vested unless a condition precedent to the vesting is expressed with reasonable clearness.

In re Edwards  5 . In support of the second principle enunciated by Mr. Sastri he has relied on the decision of the Privy Council in Bickersteth Another v. Shanu 6 . In that case the Privy Council held that the established rule for construing devises of real estate is that they are held to be vested unless a condition precedent to the vesting is expressed with reasonable clearness. On the other hand, the learned Attorney-General has invited our attention to a decision of this Court in Gnanambal Ammal T. Raju Ayyar Others 7 ,

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; Supreme Court upholds lower courts' construction of the will denying appellant any vested or contingent right under clause 12; rights only if adopted under clause 11
